Description: This summer program is based on one of Notre Dame’s most popular undergraduate courses. Using alcohol as a case study, participants explore the persuasive power visual storytelling has in shaping our beliefs and altering our actions. Students will also get a sneak peek at life at Notre Dame while living on campus for the duration of the course.

Name: Summer Scholars | Entrepreneurial Immersion
Location and Deadline:
University of Notre Dame 
Application Deadline: February 20
Description: This summer program asks participants how to use a vision to advance the common good and make the world a better place. Participants will focus on developing early-stage business ideas, testing customer interest, and understanding how to pitch to potential investors. Students will live and learn on Notre Dame’s campus for the duration of the program.

University of Puget Sound 
Application Deadline: March 6
Description: Canada/USA Mathcamp is a five-week-long summer camp for high school students with demonstrated potential and aptitude in mathematics to enhance their abilities, skills, and confidence in the subject. Mathcamp enrolls 65 new students each summer, as well as 55 returning alumni. The Qualifying Quiz, a personal essay, recommendation letters, and prior mathematical knowledge are used to determine whether applicants are accepted.

Location and Deadline:
University of Rochester
Application Deadline: N/A
Description: The University of Rochester offers a multitude of summer programs for high schoolers, including both full- and half-day programs, credit- and non-credit-bearing, as well as residential and commuter offerings, to cater to a wide range of preferences and interests. Programs are offered in fields like engineering, medicine, business, and the humanities.

Name: University of Saint Joseph Connecticut Challenge Program
USC Bovard Scholars
Description: Bovard Scholars live on the USC campus, getting a taste of college life while learning in a rigorous curriculum. They also receive hands-on support and mentorship from a coach who will guide them through the college admissions process, assisting them with their applications and essays. Following the program, their admissions coach will continue to work with them through the admissions process and offer assistance.

Name: Summer Programs for Academically and Artistically Talented Youth (SPAATY)
Health Sciences Summer Camps
Description: Note that, while there is also an open application, 75% of participants in this program are nominated by their school district. If you’re interested, you should speak to your school counselor or science teacher about how to secure a nomination, as the process varies from district to district and from school to school.

Name: Subiendo: The Academy for Rising Leaders
Location and Deadline:
University of Texas at Austin 
Application Deadline: February 14
Description: Subiendo is a competitive program hosted by UT Austin for rising juniors and seniors in high school. The program introduces students to the well-regarded McCombs School of Business through leadership seminars, case studies, campus visits, and tours with current students.

Name: University of the Pacific Summer Camps

Young Scholars Summer STEMM Research Program
Description: This program, offered by the prestigious Grainger College of Engineering at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC), allows students to gain hands-on research experience in fields such as cancer immunology, AI, physics, quantum mechanics, and electrical engineering. They will also build valuable general life skills by participating in seminars on topics ranging from the college admission process to how to communicate scientifically.

Name: Philadelphia International Music Festival (PIMF)
Location and Deadline: Valley Forge Military Academy and College

Name: NASA OSTEM Internship
Description: NASA offers a variety of internships for high school students across its numerous campuses. Interns gain real-world work experience by working side by side with research scientists and engineers, which will strengthen their resume and help prepare them for their eventual careers. All participants must be at least 16 years old and enrolled in high school full time.

Name: Bank of America Student Leaders Program
Description: The Bank of America Student Leaders program prepares a diverse group of community-minded young people for success in the workforce through leadership training. While employed in these eight-week paid internships, high school juniors and seniors will gain firsthand experience working with nonprofits such as the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and Habitat for Humanity.

Name: Global Leadership Adventures
Description: Designed for students ages 14 to 18, Global Leadership Adventures is a program for student travelers who want to learn to become global leaders through international cultural travel and immersion in a foreign country of their choosing. During GLA’s programs, students gain leadership skills through language learning and volunteering in a foreign country.

Gap Year Programs with The School of The New York Times

AI Neuharth Free Spirit and Journalism Conference

WSU Engineering Summer Camps
Description: Do you love to build things? Want to spend a week engineering a drone or programming a robot? If so, you might like Wichita State University’s Engineering Summer Camps.

Name: WPU Summer Camps for Rising 9th-12th Graders
PEAK Summer Program
Description: Spiritual high school juniors and seniors with an interest in both academics and the outdoors will want to check out this summer program. Time is divided between studying the “Great Books” and participating in outdoor activities like horseback riding, rock climbing, and rappelling. Participants will even take a four-day backpacking trip. Despite the packed schedule, time is always made for resting in prayer and the sacraments.

Name: SOAR X
Location and Deadline:
Xavier University of Louisiana
Application Deadline: April 30
Description: Stress on Analytical Reasoning (SOAR) X is an intensive, four-week residential program designed to help prepare the next generation of highly educated professionals for success in, and after, college.

Name: Yale Young Global Scholars
Description: The Yale Young Global Scholars program is a competitive summer experience for current high school sophomores or juniors. YYGS offers sessions covering topics including politics, STEM, global literature and culture, and solving global challenges. During the program, students will attend lectures and discussions as well as work on an overarching capstone project culminating in a final student showcase.

Name: Yunasa West
Description: Yunasa West in Colorado is a program specifically designed for gifted youth. Students take part in traditional camp activities, as well as special workshops designed for gifted children to learn more about themselves and gain greater awareness and self-acceptance. The program is led by experts in the field of gifted education.

Name: Youth Actors Academy of Lincoln (YAAL) Summer Camps
YWCA Young Women’s Leadership Corps (YWLC) Summer Institute
Connecticut College Pre-College Program | Venture Incubator
American Sleep Medicine Foundation High School Video Contest
World of 8 Billion Student Video Contest
The All-American High School Film Festival (AAHSFF)
Thunder Bay International Film Festival Student Film Competition
Austin Film Festival Young Filmmakers Competition
The High School 48 Hour Film Project
The International Ocean Film Festival Student Film Competition
Yellowstone Writing Project’s Rural Journalism Camp
Harvard Summer School’s Secondary School Program Online
Description: Harvard Summer School’s Secondary School Program Online is a seven-week program where students can take classes in a variety of subjects taught by Harvard faculty. Though the program is virtual, those taking classes remotely can get a taste of college academics while building connections with other students from around the country.

Name: Iowa Young Writers’ Studio
Description: The Iowa Young Writers’ Studio, hosted by the University of Iowa, is a summer program for high school students interested in creative writing. The program provides students with the opportunity to study with graduates of one of the most renowned writing programs in the nation—the Iowa Writers’ Workshop.

Name: Economics for Leaders
Description: The Foundation for Teaching Economics offers leadership seminars that teach economics at college campuses across the country to interested current high school sophomores and juniors. If none of the host schools are near where you live, they also offer the program virtually. Over the course of a week, students will learn about fundamental economics concepts and develop economic reasoning skills, as well as their leadership, during “live” online lectures and activities.

Name: LaunchX
Description: LaunchX is a program for high school students who want to learn how to design and develop a successful startup company. The program invites expert guest speakers to discuss the process and the logistics of beginning and maintaining a startup.

Name: New York Film Academy Online Summer Camps
Description: Through New York Film Academy’s online summer camps, students can learn about creation and performance in a medium of their choice—filmmaking, acting for film, or 3D animation. Students receive live interactive instruction, participate in group meetings, and complete practical, creative projects, all while learning about the exciting world of storytelling through film.

Name: NYU Tisch Online High School Filmmakers Workshop
Description: Hosted by the famed NYU Tisch School of the Arts, the High School Filmmakers Workshop allows students to work together online with other emerging artists on skill-building film projects. In one-on-one virtual meetings with experienced instructors, participants will learn to develop their writing, directing, shooting, and editing skills in order to produce a variety of short films.

Name: NYU Tisch Online High School Screenwriters Workshop
Description: In this program, which is hosted by NYU Tisch School of the Arts, students will participate in intensive screenwriting exercises to learn the basic principles of writing for film and television. Students will have the opportunity to develop story ideas and characters while learning film language and script structure. There will also be workshops where students will analyze important works, as well as have a dialogue about each other’s works.

Name: High School Conservatory at The American Musical and Dramatic Academy Summer Conservatory
Description: Hosted by The American Musical and Dramatic Academy, the High School Summer Conservatory offers two-week virtual programs in two fields—Musical Theatre and Acting. In each of these programs, students will participate in an immersive and rigorous exploration of their chosen domain. Besides learning essential fundamental skills from industry professionals, participants will produce works of their own.

Name: Boston Architectural College Summer Academy for High School Students
Description: In this program offered by Boston Architectural College, students will gain a deeper understanding of fields like architecture, interior design, and landscape design. Virtual participants will explore case study buildings, attend virtual site and professional firm visits, and receive kits in the mail to participate in hands-on design and building.

Name: The AFSF Build San Francisco Summer Design Institute
Description: This summer program offered by the Architectural Foundation of San Francisco provides high school students with many tools and skills that will help them succeed in the world of architectural design. Students will receive one-on-one professional feedback and guidance from architects and engineers, as well as instruction in computer-aided design tools—including SketchUp and the Autodesk family of modeling software.

Name: Stanford University Mathematics Camp (SUMaC)
Description: In a three-week virtual experience, SUMaC participants immerse themselves in advanced mathematics through activities such as lectures, guided research, and group problem-solving. Students engage in daily problem sets, work with teaching assistant Stanford students, and attend virtual guest lectures from mathematicians and others who use mathematics in their respective fields.

Name: Tufts Leadership for Social Change
Description: Open to rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors, the Tufts Leadership for Social Change pre-college program helps students develop their leadership skills. Participants will discuss issues including educational inequities, environmental justice, public policy, and more. They will also develop change-making skills, resiliency strategies, and civic knowledge to build connections, work collaboratively, and emerge as agents of change who can inspire others.

Name: The Adroit Journal Summer Mentorship Program
Description: The Adroit Journal Summer Mentorship Program, hosted by The Adroit Journal, gives high school students, graduating seniors, and gap year students the opportunity to work with experienced writers and to explore the creative writing process of drafting, redrafting, and editing. Instead of traditional class instruction, the program offers flexible, individualized correspondence to students interested in poetry, fiction, creative nonfiction, or memoir.

Name: Boston University Summer Journalism Academy
Description: In BU’s Summer Journalism Academy, high school students will have the opportunity to develop their writing skills and learn journalism from real working journalists and reporters. Each lesson is bolstered by practical, real-world applications and actual reporting assignments that will help participants learn what a news reporter’s life is like. Students can choose between two domains—News Reporting and Writing, and Photojournalism.

Name: Columbia Scholastic Press Association Summer Journalism Workshop
Description: Hosted by the Columbia Scholastic Press Association at Columbia University, this program unites high school students interested in developing their journalistic skills. During the program, students develop interviewing and reporting skills. Students can choose to study mediums focused on a number of skill sets—writing, editing, design, photojournalism, and leadership.

Name: Columbia Online Summer
Description: Participants in Columbia’s pre-college programs will not only get to dive into the university’s world-class academic offerings in their areas of interest, but also bond with their peers and learn more about how to succeed in college. Students who participate in the program for two weeks will also have the opportunity to take part in a workshop on college essay writing.

Name: Girls Who Code
Description: Girls Who Code offers two free summer programs for young female and non-binary high schoolers ages 14 through 18: a two-week-long immersion program and a self-paced program. Both programs introduce participants to careers in tech, deliver hands-on computer science experience, and help cultivate a community of like-minded peers.

Name: UC San Diego FUTURES Programs
Description: UC San Diego’s FUTURES programs introduce high schoolers to potential college and career paths. Courses range in length and are self-paced, so that even the most time-crunched high schoolers can squeeze them into their busy schedules. Programs are designed specifically for high school students and offered in a number of in-demand fields, including business management, front end web development, and machine learning.

Name: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee: Virtual Architecture Summer Camp Academy
Description: This summer program for high schoolers in grades 9 through 12 is a great choice for students interested in architecture and design. Students participate in hands-on activities and workshops to learn how to communicate their ideas through models, drawing text, and presentations while also gaining an understanding of how to use digital models, read architectural drawings, and document their work.

Name: BETA Camp
Description: Participants in BETA Camp tackle an MBA-inspired curriculum designed especially for high schoolers. Students are thrust into the startup world and tasked with building a revenue-generating business that solves a real problem. Along the way, they learn business fundamentals, explore career opportunities, receive mentorship from experienced entrepreneurs, and build skills like teamwork and communication.

Name: Summer Springboard UX/UI Design Online
Description: This summer program provides students with real-world knowledge of UX/UI design, by helping them better understand the UX design process and how to create meaningful products. While honing their fundamental design skills, students will explore how humans interact with computers, how to incorporate research into the design process, and how to build a visual identity. Students will test their newfound skills with a hands-on project and develop a prototype using their research and analysis.

Name: University of Pennsylvania: Wharton Global Youth Program: Essentials of Leadership
Description: This program introduces students in grades 9 through 12 to undergraduate business education and helps them build skills that will serve them in college and beyond like emotional intelligence, problem solving, communication, teamwork, and collaboration. Students will take part in business simulations, discuss business topics with peers and instructors, and participate in experiential learning opportunities.

Name: University of Massachusetts Juniper Young Writers Online
Description: Young wordsmiths in grades 9 through 12 can share their creativity, writing, and ideas with a community of their peers in this summer program. Over the course of the week-long program, students will develop their craft, draw inspiration from their peers, and receive advice as they participate in writing labs, readings, craft sessions, and life talks.

Each session in the Fashion Design covers different topics, so in order to get the most comprehensive experience, your student might consider attending both summer sessions.

Over the course of five days, students will sharpen their observation, creativity, and intellectual skills while learning about the career opportunities available in forensic science.

Name: Intensive Study in Forensic Science

Students will also need to submit their current grades and be recommended by a math, science, or technology teacher. Lastly, students are asked to write an essay explaining why they’re interested in participating in this program.

Name: Anatomy 101
Description: High schoolers entering this six-day, five-night residential program will learn about the different fields of study and career paths available in aviation. Students will explore a variety of aviation-related subjects, take flights in Saint Louis University airplanes with certified flight instructors, go on field trips, and get the opportunity to tour the campus.

Name: Aviation Summer Academy
Description: Future engineers will learn about fields such as aerospace, mechanical, biomedical, computer, electrical, and civil engineering in this six-day, five-night residential program. Taught by Parks College of Engineering, Aviation, and Technology faculty with help from student mentors, high schoolers will learn about careers in engineering and sample campus life.

Name: Engineering Summer Academy
Description: The perfect program for the high schooler who wants to pursue a career in cooking. Over the course of this week-long program, students will work with chefs, dietitians, and gardeners—learning how to prepare meals as well as gaining insight into nutrition, gardening, and healthy lifestyles.

Name: Gardens to Tables Culinary Camp
Description: Students with an interest in theatre will love this program hosted by Saint Louis University and the Metro Theatre Company. Covering a variety of areas such as acting, movement, and audition techniques, students will both create original work and perform scenes from well-known works. This five-day camp culminates with a performance for friends and family.

Name: Grand Theater Camp: High School
Description: An awesome opportunity for aspiring writers, students in this five-day program will learn about writing across various genres. Collaboration is key in this course, and students will provide one another with constructive feedback and criticism to improve their writing.

Name: Gifted Arts: High School Creative Writing
Description: An awesome opportunity for aspiring writers, students in this five-day program will learn about writing across various genres. Collaboration is key in this course, and students will provide one another with constructive feedback and criticism to improve their writing.

Name: Gifted Arts: High School Visual Arts
Description: Your class clown will study the art of improvisation in this fun five-day program from The Improv Shop and Saint Louis University. Students will learn how to think on the fly and nurture a sense of spontaneity by participating in a variety of games and exercises. This program concludes with a performance for friends and family.

Name: Improvisational Comedy Camp
Description: A great program for high schoolers considering college majors in technology fields, this five-day program provides an introduction to essential STEM skills. Students will be taught how to write code to create applications and information technology tools. At the conclusion of the program, students will present their final coding projects.

Name: Introduction to Coding & Information Technology
Description: This program is a  great introduction to the majors and career paths available to high schoolers interested in engineering. Over the course of five days, students will participate in hands-on activities in fields like mechanical, biomedical, computer, electrical, and civil engineering.

Name: Introduction to Engineering Camp
Description: High schoolers can prepare for a career in healthcare while learning about anatomy. Over the course of the program’s five days, students will hear from physicians and healthcare professionals, get hands-on experience in the lab, interact with patients, and view surgical demonstrations.

Name: Medical and Surgical Procedures
Description: For tech enthusiasts, this course fully immerses high schoolers into the development of apps for Android and Apple using Google’s Flutter. This five-day course will show students what it takes to bring an app from an idea to a fully functioning program available on the Apple and Android libraries.

Name: Mobile App Development with Flutter by Google (Apps for Android and Apple iOS)
Programming and Development with Java

Name: Center Stage Strings
Description: High school clarinetists will develop strong fundamentals, improve tone production, and enhance technical skills in this week-long program.

Name: Dance Institute
Description: Taught by Maximilian Dimoff, the Associate Professor of Double Bass at the University of Michigan and Principal Bassist of The Cleveland Orchestra, students in this week-long course will focus on developing fundamentals, solo repertoire, orchestral excerpts, and chamber music with extra attention paid to college audition prep.

Name: Double Bass Institute
Description: This one-week program aimed at serious high school flutists instructs in tone, technique, and intonation while also covering topics like body awareness, performance anxiety, and teaching techniques from productive practice.

Name: Flute Institute
Description: High school harpists will receive individual instruction to enhance their musical and technical skills with a focus on college preparation and performance concentration in this intensive week-long program.

Name: Jazz Institute
Description: Designed for high schoolers planning on pursuing a BFA degree in college, students in this three-week program will cover a wide range of topics taught by faculty members from the University of Michigan’s Department of Musical Theatre, the Department of Theatre and Drama, and the Department of Dance. By the end of this course, students will have a clear understanding of the college application and audition process.

Name: Musical Theatre Workshop
Description: This five-day program for high-achieving high school students focuses on the role of genomics in diseases and symptoms. Using patient RNA expression data, students will perform computational biology research to identify genes related to particular diseases.

Name: Computational Biology Camp
Description: Ideal for high school students with an interest in computers, math, science, and medicine, this five-day program combines UNIX, wet-lab techniques (including PCR and gel-electrophoresis), and thermodynamics calculation of nucleotide hybridization to teach nucleotide biotechnology.

Name: Biotechnology Camp
Description: Over the course of five days, students in this program will study the role of genomics in diseases and symptoms—learning to identify genes related to certain diseases using computational biology.

Name: R Programming Camp
Description: Sponsored by the Scripps Research Institute, this program is a fantastic starting point for high schoolers to build a network of peers at a similar level and with common interests. Over the program’s five days, students will get hands-on experience with computational genomics and learn how to use R packages and basic programming.

Name: Computational Biology Research Camp
Description: High schoolers who aspire to be architects will love this three-week residential program focused on preparing them for a future at a leading design institution. The curriculum covers a wide range of skills including hand drawing, model making, diagramming, and sketching while reinforcing analytical and conceptual problem-solving skills.

Name: ArcStart
Description: Aimed at the business leaders of tomorrow, this two-week program will educate and equip high schoolers for leadership positions—nurturing and strengthening their inner entrepreneurs. Students will learn about business communication techniques to prepare for presenting themselves in a positive light.

Name: Business Communication and Presentation Camp
Description: Want access to expert college guidance — for free? When you create your free CollegeVine account, you will find out your real admissions chances, build a best-fit school list, learn how to improve your profile, and get your questions answered by experts and peers—all for free. Sign up for your CollegeVine account today to get a boost on your college journey.

Name: CREHST (Clinical Research Experience for High School Students)
Hugh N. Boyd Journalism Diversity Workshop for New Jersey High School Students
Leadership Summer Academy
Description: Essay Requirements: This essay should be a maximum of one page, double-spaced. In the essay, please address one of the following:

Name: Music Theory and Ear Training Bootcamp
Biosciences & Engineering Camp for High School
Description: A one-week crash course in college prep, rising seniors are encouraged to participate in this intensive experience to develop high-quality admissions materials. Students will receive individualized meetings with admissions counselors, develop their college essays, and begin filling out the Common App and Coalition Apps. They will also prepare resumes and participate in mock interviews, to make sure every aspect of their application is as strong as possible.

Name: Duke College Admissions Boot Camp
Description: If your student loves to solve puzzles, then this is the summer program for them. During this two-week camp, students will learn the mathematical foundations for cryptography and master elementary coding in Python to practice their own code-writing. They’ll also participate in code-cracking races and scavenger hunts across Duke’s beautiful campus, applying their skills in an engaging way.

Name: Cracking the Code: High School Crypto-Camp
Description: This two week program is perfect for students who are committed to making the world a better place. During the Leadership in Action Institute, students will learn about local, national, and global issues affecting our society through case studies, group discussions, and written assignments. They’ll also take action directly by volunteering in the Durham community and developing a plan for progress that they can implement in their own community.

Name: Leadership in Action Institute
Description: As part of the Duke TIP program, students can choose two classes that explore a field in greater depth, which means that students can mix-and-match this class with the other TIP classes below. Students will learn the basic elements of screenwriting in this class, and will draw inspiration from a variety of sources to develop their own characters and storylines.

Name: Duke TIP | Big Screen, Little Screen: Writing for the Camera
Description: The best introduction to advanced computer skills, students will learn how to develop programs that satisfy scientific and engineering needs, explore the current uses of computers in these industries, and develop a foundation in topics like data processing, laboratory equipment control, computation, and graphical analysis.

Name: Duke TIP | Computer Skills for Today’s Scientists and Engineers
Description: With the popularity of Hamilton, Making a Murderer, and Serial, our society is seeing more imaginative and artful representations of history and journalism. This course allows students to research a historical figure, learn about the period in which they lived, and use that knowledge to inform their attempt at writing that person’s memoir using established narrative practices.

Name: Duke TIP | Creative Chronicles: The Intersection of Narrative and History
Duke TIP | Dictators, Kings, and CEOs: The Evolution of Empire
Description: This program combines ethics and media analysis to determine what our societal ethical principles might be, which principles we should use to interpret and understand our world, and if “white lies” can ever be justified. Students will also examine how the media impacts our understanding of ethics, just as ethics shapes our media.

Name: Duke TIP | Ethics and the Little White Lie
Description: Students will discover how game theory, or Formal Decision Theory, helps people navigate complex decision-making processes. Not only will they apply game theory to case studies and hypothetical situations, but they’ll also learn how game theory has applications in broader contexts such as conflict and warfare, evolution, psychology, and sociology.

Name: Duke TIP | History of the Future
Description: Perfect for students interested in politics, history, or international relations, this program explores concepts such as war, international trade, human rights, and the tensions between societal challenges and individual action. They’ll also look at historical conflicts to understand the possible ramifications of current conflicts.

Name: Duke TIP | Literary License without Limits
Description: Students will walk away from this course with a introductory college-level understanding of macroeconomics. They’ll learn how to determine income levels and employment, explore government spending and consumer consumption and their effects on the economy, and be able to participate in political and economic debates in an informed way.

Name: Duke TIP | Macroeconomics
Description: Like the Macroeconomics course, this intensive course provides an introduction to college-level microeconomics. Students will learn how to use microeconomics as a model for understanding human behavior, and how individuals and businesses try to maximize their resources. They’ll also explore how some controversial policies affect individuals, such as minimum wage laws, farm subsidies, rent controls, and welfare programs.

Name: Duke TIP | Microeconomics
Description: Whether your teen knows exactly what they want to study or still wants to explore their options, there’s a program that caters to their interests. As a school committed to providing enriching opportunities for students, Duke offers a variety of programs to help students find success on their terms.

Name: Martin W. Essex School for the Gifted and Talented
Description: Additional requirements: A sample of your gift or passion (academic, creative, artistic, leadership, or talent); for example, a piece of writing, a series of photographs, a video, a piece of music, or a choreographed dance

Name: Women of Color Engineering Summer Camp
Men of Color Engineering Summer Camp
The Young Writers Workshop
Description: Additional requirements:

Name: Ohio Business Week
Description: Additional requirements: Minimum 2.0 GPA

Name: Camp Muskingum
Description: An ideal summer program for outdoorsy high schoolers, the FFA Camp sits at an intersection of the traditional camp experience and an educational academic opportunity. Activities will include campfires, a talent show, forestry lessons, and more. If you’re interested in conservation, wildlife, or the great outdoors, the week-long FFA Camp might be the program for you.

Name: 3D Animation
Description: During this one-week intensive, students will brush up on all aspects of performance through workshops and ensemble-building activities. They’ll also get a professional headshot to use for their auditions and see a show in the exciting cultural center of downtown Atlanta.

Name: American Sign Language for Hearing Adolescents
Description: Students get an inside look at the career of an architect as they learn the basic skills of perspective drawing and design. They’ll study past architectural designs that have impacted current practice, learn about the practical aspects of designing a home such as electricity, water, heating and cooling, and work in teams to develop a scale model of a house they designed.

Name: Architecture & Design
Description: Give your student the opportunity to earn certifications in Child Development Leadership & Service and Basic First Aid this summer! Students will explore the different aspects of early childhood development and observe infant, toddlers, and preschool age students in their classrooms to enhance their understanding.

Name: Child Development 101
Description: This exciting introduction to college will motivate your student to pursue their academic goals. Over the course of a week, students will not only explore the opportunities available at UGA, but they’ll also visit other colleges and universities around Athens and learn about the admissions requirements for each school.

Name: College Preview
Description: A self-paced program for students who love visual storytelling, students will learn how to develop characters and storylines as they practice drawing and inking techniques to bring their ideas to life. There are workshops designed for specific skill-levels or interests, so students can pursue what makes the most sense for their creative projects.

Name: Comic Books
Description: This is the perfect introduction to writing a story from start to finish. Students will learn different techniques for developing their ideas, participate in hands-on activities to refine details and workshop with their fellow writers. By the end of the camp, students will know what steps to take to complete any piece of writing they start.

Name: Culinary Skills
Description: As part of a small student crew, students will write, direct, and produce their own short film. Each crew works with an experienced filmmaker to learn the skills required for screenwriting, camera angles, and video editing to create their final product. UGA encourages students to bring a flash drive so students can keep a copy of their film.

Name: Digital Film
Description: Students will learn about one of the most useful topics in science during this introductory one-week camp. They’ll explore physical concepts related to electricity and apply their learning to design their own circuits. Each day they’ll have to find the solution for an increasingly difficult challenge using electricity and circuits.

Name: Introductory Engineering: Exploring Electricity
Description: Geared towards students who are serious about a career in engineering, this one-week program allows students to experience the life of an engineer. They’ll learn about different engineering fields directly from professionals and develop a project in either electrical, mechanical, civil, computer systems, biological/agricultural, biomedical, chemical, or environmental engineering.

Name: Advanced Engineering
Description: Perfect for the students who love the outdoors and want to learn more about it, students will spend their days in the outdoor classroom of the State Botanical Gardens. They’ll learn about horticulture, conversation, herpetology, and botany as they learn about careers in these fields from experts.

Name: Exploring Environmental Sciences
Description: Your student will learn the entire process of developing fashion, from sketching to sewing, during this one-week program. They’ll draw inspiration from legendary designers and meet a working fashion designer to get insight into the professional world. By the end of the week, students will have the start to their own design portfolio.

Name: Fashion Design
Description: In this camp, students will learn the basic design elements of different types of games, including tabletop, board, card, miniature, and role-playing games (RPGs). Either working in groups or independently, students will develop an original game idea and create the rules and game components such as cards, dice, boards, and more, before sharing their creation with the public.

Name: Game Design for Tabletop & RPGs
Description: UGA summer programs run the gamut of experiences. Whether your teen knows exactly what they want to study or wants to explore their options, there’s a program that caters to their interests. No matter which program they choose, they are sure to get unique insight into what it’s really like to get in and attend an Ivy League school.

Name: Penn Summer Prep Program
Description: Students will develop their research and leadership skills in this three-week program. They’ll dive into historical movements such as the American revolution, suffrage, and civil rights, and explore present-day struggles such as environmentalism, LGBTQ rights, and Black Lives Matter. Students will attend a mix of class lectures and site visits around Philadelphia, and develop a research capstone project to synthesize their new insights.

Name: Penn Summer Academies | Social Justice Research Academy
Penn Summer Academies | Biomedical Research Academy
Penn Summer Academies | Chemistry Research Academy
Penn Summer Academies | Experimental Physics Academy
Penn Summer Academies | Neuroscience Research Academy
Leadership in the Business World
Description: Students can earn college credit upon completion of this summer program that blends business and engineering. They will learn about resources available at Penn, attend lectures where they explore concepts related to technological entrepreneurship, and use their newly-acquired knowledge to build a prototype and develop a market plan for an innovative product of their own design.

Name: Management & Technology Summer Institute
Description: If your student is thinking about attending law school after college, then you may want to encourage them to apply for this program. This three-week program introduces basic law concepts such as contracts, torts, constitutional and criminal law, and allows students to specialize in a legal area of their choice: either Business and Entrepreneurship Law or Human Rights and Legal Advocacy.

Name: Penn Law Pre-College Summer Academy
Description: UPenn summer programs run the gamut of experiences. Whether your teen knows exactly what they want to study or wants to explore their options, there’s a program that caters to their interests. No matter which program they choose, they are sure to get unique insight into what it’s really like to get in and attend an Ivy League school.

Description: Cornell summer programs run the gamut of experiences. Whether your teen knows exactly what they want to study or wants to explore their options, there’s a program that caters to their interests. No matter which program they choose, they are sure to get unique insight into what it’s really like to get in and attend an Ivy League school.

Name: Tisch Summer High School Program
Description: All of the Tisch Summer High School Programs are open to 10th-11th graders and have an application deadline of January 9, 2019.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Drama
Description: This track provides aspiring dancers with technical choreography and performance training that emphasizes the importance of critical thought and creativity within the world of dance.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Dance
Description: Students are given the exciting opportunity to learn the fundamentals of dramatic structure while  developing their own plays and screenplays. During this program, participants will workshop and present their creative work in the Rita and Burton Goldberg Theatre.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Writing
Description: Through hands-on and dynamic instruction, students will learn about various approaches to film and narrative storytelling. Additionally, over the course of the program, high schoolers will have access to Tisch’s professional digital camera and sound equipment to help bring their creative visions to life.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Filmmaking
Description: This summer program explores the foundational elements of digital game development and design such as programming, visual arts, animation, sound design, and writing. Ultimately, over the course of 4-weeks, students will gain a true understanding of the artistry that underpins game design.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Game Design
NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Photography
Description: Explore the fast paced world of music recording and music business through this unique summer program! Over the course of 4 weeks, students will gain instruction on cutting edge studio hardware and ultimately create their own musical recordings.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Tisch | Recorded Music
NYU Precollege
Description: Tell us about who you are, as a student and a person, in 250-500 words (approximately 1 page typed). You may select a topic of your choice, or answer the following question: Describe an experience that has impacted who you are as a person. What is special, unique, distinctive or impressive about you or your life story?

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Coding for Game Design
Description: This 2-week program aims to introduce high schoolers to the basics of robotics, mechatronics and programming. With an emphasis on hands-on learning, students will learn how to use micro-controllers, interface sensors and actuators using a robotics kit. Additionally, this program will provide high schoolers with an overview of the history of robotics and a look into the future of the dynamic field.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Summer Program for Automation Robotics and Coding (SPARC)
Description: This 3-week commuter summer program looks to encourage and empower historically underrepresented populations in STEM. Through hands on learning and projects, students will gain a fundamental understanding of cyber security and computer science at the NYU Tandon School of Engineering.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Computer Science for Cyber Security (CS4CS)
Description: Over the course of 3 weeks, students can gain an introduction to college level math topics while building upon their skills of problem solving and analysis. The courses provided by this commuter program are led by Courant faculty and graduate students and emphasize collaborative learning.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | CALI
Description: Find the music program that aligns with your interest whether it be music technology or vocal performance! All offered programs are supported by New York University’s Steinhardt Department of Music.

Name: NYU Summer Programs | Steinhardt Music and Performing Arts Programs
NYU Summer Programs | Girl’s STEM
Description: If your high schooler needs help finding and applying to summer programs that align with their interests and long term goals, don’t hesitate to reach out to teachers and guidance counselors for insight on programs that may fit your student’s needs!

Name: Acting I
Description: Taught by an Ithaca Psychology professor, this course looks at how physiological, cognitive, social, and personality factors influence behavior. Students will discuss important theories in psychology and research and examine how psychology is relevant to their own lives.

Name: General Psychology
Description: In this course, students listen to guest speakers and discuss topics across a wide range of health specialties, including physical therapy, athletic training, nutrition, sex education, medicine, nursing, and more. Students also participate in clinic site visits on and off campus, discover career options, and examine major contemporary health issues.

Name: Health Sciences: Foundations and Careers
Description: Viewing popular culture through the lens of communication and media, students learn about how rhetoric influences us, from the impact of social media to the clothing we wear to the television and films we consume. Participants will look at methods of media and communication studies, such as underlying political messages in Black Panther, Game of Thrones, and more. They will also gain an understanding of how messages are created, participating in lectures, small-group discussions, multimedia presentations, and field trips.

Name: Media and Communication Studies
Description: Is your child planning on pursuing a degree in musical theater? If so, this course will help them beat the odds by learning the ins and outs of the audition process. Covering topics such as what judges look for in an audition tape, selecting songs, and even what to wear, students will perform two prepared songs and receive critiques on the first day of class. They will then study and work on songs under the guidance of a vocal coach throughout the course.The program culminates in a showcase, where students perform in front of peers, family, and faculty and staff.

Name: Musical Theater Performance
Description: Exploring topics and readings while engaging in PRAXIS, the process of “learning-action-reflection-reformulation,” students will delve into the social world. Readings, films, discussions, role-playing, papers, and more will help students gain an understanding of sociology as they apply course material to current events and prepare an end-of-course presentation.

Name: Introduction to Sociology
Description: Students interested in studying sports media will gain a valuable introduction to this exciting topic. Studying areas including print, broadcast, Internet, and social media platforms, they will gain experience writing their own material while learning about media delivery and the skills required for success in the industry. They will also explore career options in sports media.

Name: Sports Media
Description: Check out  our pre-college summer programs guide to learn about even more programs and select one that’s right for you.

Name: Television Studio Production
Description: High schoolers will gain real research experience, assisting Ithaca faculty and undergraduates with lab and field research across Biology, Chemistry, Physics and Astronomy, and Environmental Studies and Sciences. As part of the experience, they will also observe lectures and panel discussions and participate in social activities.

Name: American Sign Language
Description: Delving into the world of Pro Tools, the “industry standard” digital audio workstation across many digital media industries, students will learn about important digital audio concepts ranging from microphones and MIDI to editing and final mixdown. They will explore how to work and speak with technical and creative professions while gaining real experience in a professional recording studio environment.

Name: Digital Music Production
Description: Budding photographers will delve into the world of digital photography, covering topics such as camera use and imaging. Students will also create their own new artwork using advanced Photoshop techniques.

Name: Digital Photography
Description: Fashion aficionados and future designers will discover the process of clothing construction, materials specifics, how to make alterations to improve fit, and why some articles of clothing work and look better than others. Students do not need sewing experience to participate in this course.

Name: Fashion Essentials
Description: Is your student interested in the fascinating world of gaming? This course explores the fundamentals of games and psychology of play. Covering topics such as game mechanics, storytelling, interest curves, usability, implementation, and more, students will build their own 2D computer games using the introductory game design tool Stencyl.

Name: Game Design
Description: Looking for more summer programs in New York State? Check out our New York Summer Programs guide.

UIUC Engineering High School Summer STEM Research Programs

Name: University of Chicago Research in the Biological Sciences
Description: Interested in how the world’s leading scholars approach problems in their fields? Consider enrolling in one of UChicago’s three-week Pathways programs, featuring nine topic areas ranging from molecular engineering to human rights. Taught by faculty members and staffed by UChicago students, these programs are valuable for both learning and making connections at one of the top schools in the nation. Note that transcripts, a letter of recommendation, and a writing sample are required to complete the application.

Name: LaunchX at Northwestern University
Description: Deadline: February 25, 2019

Name: Northwestern College Preparation Program: Courses for Credit
Description: Deadline: May 1, 2019

Name: Illinois Aerospace Institute Summer Camp
Description: Deadline: March 1, 2019

Name: Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program
Description: Sponsored by the Army Research Office, HSAP gives high school students the opportunity to learn about research methods and develop skills used in Army critical research areas while working with researchers in a university lab setting.

Name: High School Apprenticeship Program
Description: Working under the direct supervisor of a mentor, talented, underserved students participate in a hands-on research project at local colleges and universities. In addition to gaining real-world research experience and mentorship, they will learn about career opportunities in STEM and receive a stipend for their participation.

Name: Research & Engineering Apprenticeship Program
Description: Hosted by Maryland Institute College of Art, one of the country’s premier art institutes, high schoolers will learn from expert faculty and working artists as they earn college credit and build a portfolio for their college applications. They will also travel around Baltimore and to cities such as New York, Washington, D.C., or Philadelphia. Five-, three-, or two-week options are available.

Name: Summer Science Academy | Zombie Science
Description: Students conduct practical laboratory experiments and fieldwork in marine ecology, biological oceanography, and physical oceanography in this week-long course. They will also have the opportunity to participate in a field trip on a working oceanographic research vessel.

Name: Morgan State Summer Academy of Mathematics and Science
Description: Residential and commuter students get a taste of college life and have the opportunity to earn three college credits during this summer program at UMD. They will choose from courses across a wide range of disciplines and participate in activities and workshops, such as fitness and drawing. Students will also take a weekend day trip to Washington, D.C. and take part in social activities.

Name: Terp Young Scholars
Description: Open to young women interested in physics, this program offers hands-on activities, research labs, speakers, and more. The program is separated by age group, with entering 9th graders exploring introductory topics in physics and entering 10th and 11th graders delving into complex areas like relativity, antimatter, quantum mechanics, physical uncertainty, quantum computing and more.

Name: Physics Summer Girls Program
Description: Is your child a natural or aspiring leader? Students who are considering applying to the Naval Academy will undergo academic, athletic, and professional training while living on campus and learning from midshipmen and faculty.

Name: Summer Experience in Science and Engineering for Youth
School of Arts and Communication Academy | Choir Camp
Description: JumpstART is a weeklong program for students with an interest in studio arts and a desire to  build their skills in this field. Students participate in an accelerated program led by teaching artists, and classes are supplemented with visiting artist lectures, workshops, and excursions.

Name: School of Arts and Communication Academy | JumpstART
Description: In this weeklong camp, high school students gain experience using technology to make music. Students take classes in recording techniques, software operation, and listening skills, while exploring both the creative and technical sides of music production.

Name: School of Arts and Communication Academy | Music Recording and Production Camp
Description: The Oregon State University Veterinary Experience is for academically talented high school students interested in pursuing a career in veterinary medicine. Faculty, graduate students, and veterinary students serve as mentors for students who participate in research projects, as well as clinical activities in the veterinary teaching hospital and in off-campus settings.

Name: OSU Summer Veterinary Experience
Description: This summer program is held over the course of one or two weeks and is designed for students who excel as string musicians and are interested in pursuing the field as a career or in higher education. Participants receive expert coaching, sight reading clinics, supervised practice sessions, master classes, and the opportunity to perform with small ensembles.

Name: OSU Chamber Music Workshop
Description: CURE is a research internship program for Portland-area high school students who excel academically and come from socially or economically disadvantaged backgrounds. It is supported by the Knight Cancer Institute and the Center for Diversity and Inclusion. Students work with faculty members, while attending weekly seminars and presenting their work.

Name: Ted R. Lilley CURE Program
Description: Attending a summer program can be a transformational experience for some students, providing them with invaluable insights into the fields they want to pursue and the experiences they hope to find in higher education. In the right program, students often grow not only in terms of knowledge and skill but also in terms of self-confidence and self-awareness.

Name: PREP High School Academy
Description: The Summer Science Program (SSP) is one of the longest running pre-college programs in the country, having been founded in 1959. It provides an immersive experience with hands-on research over the course of its 39-day residential program. It aims to challenge and inspire talented and motivated high school students through four different program offerings, one of which is available at New Mexico Tech.

Name: The University of New Mexico Summer High School Programs
Research Learning Experiences Program

This three-week residential program offers a combination of college prep courses, guest speakers, field trips and hands-on workshops to students interested in the transportation industry.

Description: Students can select from 200 non-credit courses in a variety of subject areas, providing high schoolers a glimpse into the depth and breadth of classes available to Brown undergraduates.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Dyin’ Dixie? Literature and Culture of the Southern U.S.
Description: During this one-week course, students will psychoanalyze horror films through the lens of race and gender. Students will learn to critically examine how media representation shapes and reinforces our understanding and biases of “othered” bodies.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Race, Gender & Horror: Reading Psychoanalysis in American Film and Fiction
Description: This two-week course explores defining characteristic of ancient Greek theater such as the amphitheater, its ancient festival context, and the notion of tragedy vs. comedy. Through daily self-produced short videos and persuasive written responses, students will directly engage with and interpret the traditions of ancient Greek theater.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Ancient Greek Theater Production
Description: During this three-week course, students explore the field of medical humanities. They learn about the important role that qualitative skills, such observation and interpretation, play in medicine. Through interactive learning, engaging field trips, and articles by and about physicians, students will ultimately gain a more nuanced understanding of what it means to be a doctor.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Medical Diagnostics: Observation, Interpretation, the Art of Being a Better MD
Description: Grounded by the science fiction fantasy novel Binti, this course aims to interrogate themes of home, violence, power and privilege. Over the span of two weeks, students will learn to think critically about social change and justice in the context of fiction and real life.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Fiction for Social Change: Building a Shared Analysis of Justice and Community
Description: This two-week course aims to help students redefine their understanding of local and global identities within the context of colonialism. Through discussion-based learning and local mini-research projects in Providence, students will learn how to critically analyze the socio-political realities of colonialism.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Thinking Globally: Colonialism and the Making of the Modern World
Description: During this creative summer course, students will hone their critical reading and writing skills through flash fiction—micro stories that “say more by saying less.” Over the course of two weeks, students will write and workshop flash fiction pieces while reading a variety of modern authors along the way.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Writing Flash Fiction
Description: The objective of this three-week course is to introduce students to post-colonial narratives in literature and film. Though group discussion and essays, students develop a deeper understanding of race, gender, and human rights.

Name: Brown Pre-College | Narratives of Revolution and (post) Colonialism: Race, Gender, and Human Rights

Description: This two-week course probes deeper into the concept of conflict at the interpersonal, inter-group, and international levels, with an emphasis on nonviolent strategies for resolving instances of contention. For their final projects, students will develop an Action Plan that directly applies their learning to their local community.

UChicago Summer Scholars
Description: If you have a student interested in history or politics, this class might be perfect for them. In it, students explore why many of America’s political, educational, and corporate institutions still use race when science has largely agreed that race is a social construct. They will work with primary source materials and engage in thoughtful discussions with their peers.

Name: ASPIRE High School Mentoring Program
Description: Through the ASPIRE program, students gain hands-on experience in STEM fields. They get to exploring career possibilities and work at Hopkins’ Applied Physics Laboratory, the largest university-affiliated research center in the United States. While working under the guidance of mentors and researchers, students discover how the concepts they learn apply to the real world. Students are placed in areas including computer science and engineering, and there are some limited placements in chemistry, biology, biomedical engineering, and neuroscience.

Description: During this Pre-College Block course, students delve into the physics of life sciences. They’ll apply physics equations to biological systems, such as human athletic performance and the circulatory system.

Name: Applications of Nanoscience Summer Institute
Description: During this 2- or 4-week program, Students may choose to specialize in drawing, painting, photography, or sculpture. They’ll refine their talents through a combination of focused studio work, artist lectures, field trips, and a final exhibition.

Name: Art Summer Institute
Description: Students delve into the theory and practice of on-camera acting during this 2- or 4-week program. Students will learn techniques for appearing on film, preparing for auditions, and attend field trips and guest lectures.

Name: Camera Acting Summer Institute
Description: This 9-day residential program allows students to explore world arts and cultures through dance during. Students will train intensively during the day to prepare for their self-created performance at the end of the institute.

Name: Dance/Performing Arts Summer Institute
Description: Do you have a student interested in the digital arts? Students create a design media arts portfolio during this 2-week program. Students will be introduced to and hone their skills for print, web, video, and game design.

Name: Design Media Arts Summer Institute
Description: Students will immerse themselves in cinematic storytelling during this 2-week intensive program. They will use the latest technology and camera equipment to produce a short film, attend film screenings, and take a trip to a Hollywood studio.

Name: Digital Filmmaking Summer Institute
Description: This 3-week program offers students the opportunity to explore career options in economics. They will learn about factors that affect the United States and the world, and earn UCLA college credit.

Name: Economics Summer Institute
Description: Is your student thinking about a career in engineering? Students choose an engineering discipline to focus on during this 3-week program. They have the option to learn about aerospace, mechanical, electrical, or chemical engineering.

Name: Engineering Design Summer Institute
Description: Students have the opportunity to explore game development during this 2-week program. They’ll master the fundamentals of game design, create compelling characters, build game worlds, and learn programming and coding.

Name: Game Lab Summer Institute
Description: During this 1-week program, students dive into international history. They have the option to learn about the French Revolution or Indian Independence through interactive games, roleplay, and research.

Name: Immersive International Studies Summer Institute
Description: Students boost their powers of persuasion during this 1-week program. Students will become more confident in their public speaking and learn about the legal profession.

Name: Model UN Summer Institute
Description: Does your student love to bring stories to life? Students hone their musical theater skills during this 3-week intensive program. Students will participate in a conservatory-style program that encompasses acting, singing, dancing, guest workshops, and backstage operations.

Name: Musical Theatre Summer Institute
Description: Students explore nanoscience during this 1-week, hands-on program. They will master the skills needed for fluorescence microscopy, scanning probe microscopy, and electron microscopy.

Name: Nanoscale Microscopy Lab Summer Institute
Description: If your student has a strong background in chemistry, encourage them to apply for this 5-day program. They will survey diverse topics in nanoscience, such as bio-toxicity, supercapacitors, and photolithography.

Name: Nanoscience Lab Summer Institute
Description: Is your student equally interested in science and the fine arts? Students challenge traditional perspectives on art and science during this 2-week program. Students will draw connections between cutting edge scientific research and popular culture and contemporary arts.

Name: Sci/Art Lab + Studio Summer Institute
Description: During this 2- or 3-week program, students hone their architecture skills. Students will be mentored by current UCLA Architecture students, faculty and alumni for an inside look at the undergraduate design studio experience.

Name: Teen ArchStudio Summer Institute
Description: Students will refine their writing skills in this 3-week program. They will learn about effective written communication, master the timed essay, and gain insight into college admissions essays.

Name: Writing Summer Institute
Description: If the 3-week engineering program is too time-intensive for you, then this is the perfect solution! Students have the opportunity to learn about the engineering profession during this 1- or 2-week program. They will explore different engineering disciplines and the latest in engineering technology.

Name: Blueprint Signature Summer Programs—Engineering
Description: During this 1- or 2-week program, students have the opportunity to learn about the medical profession. They’ll learn first aid and CPR, tour local hospitals and hear from medical experts in a variety of fields.

Name: Blueprint Signature Summer Programs—Medicine
Description: Students have the opportunity to learn about the business profession during this 1- or 2-week program. They will learn what it takes to be an entrepreneur, marketing strategies, and the importance of developing relationships.

Name: Blueprint Signature Summer Programs—Business
Description: Is your student interested in film and entertainment? Students will take advantage of Los Angeles’ resources and opportunities during this 1- or 2-week program. They’ll master skills such as script writing, developing story arcs, and filming and editing shorts.

Name: Blueprint Signature Summer Programs—Film Studies
Description: Give your students the chance to see what it’s really like to work at a crime scene investigation. Students have the opportunity to learn about the forensic science profession during this 1- or 2-week program. This hands-on course gives students real insight into criminology methods and allows them to solve cases.

Name: Blueprint Signature Summer Programs—Forensic Science
Description: Is your student fascinated by the brain and the way we think? Students have the opportunity to learn about the psychology profession during this 1- or 2-week program. Students will explore behavioral science and current theories and advances that challenge the way we think about ourselves.

Name: Blueprint Signature Summer Programs—Psychology

Name: Lynda.com
Description: EdX is a platform for online college courses, many of which are developed and administered by top universities. These include Harvard and MIT, which jointly founded the platform in 2012. Some courses are grouped into certificate programs and other directed learning experiences. Currently, about 1,270 courses are available, and the platform has over 10 million users.

Name: The Open Education Consortium
Description: Coursera offers over 2,000 different courses, and is used by over 24 million registered users. Its variety of courses and costs is similar to that of edX. In some cases, course materials are available to view for free, but a fee is required in order to receive an official certificate of completion.

Name: edX
Description: Khan Academy course materials are free to use and also free of ads. They also include tools that parents, teachers, or tutors (or you yourself) can use to help evaluate and track your performance in a particular subject. The way that topics are broken down into individual sections makes these materials particularly appropriate for use as supplements to courses you’re taking elsewhere.

Name: Coursera
Description: Saylor Academy’s courses are self-directed, so they’ll give you a lot of flexibility in choosing your schedule and pace. Some courses may allow you to earn college credit, though this may also involve additional costs. (Be aware that not every college you might eventually attend may accept these credits; each school has its own policies.)

Name: Khan Academy
Description: Extension courses are administered by individual colleges, so their details vary from school to school. You’ll want to research programs of interest carefully to determine your options and ensure you meet any requirements, such as age limits or prerequisites.
